description: From Middle English latis, from Middle French lattis (“lathing”), from Old French lattis, from latte (“a lath”), from Frankish *latta (“a lath”), from Proto-Germanic *lattǭ, *lattō, *laþþō (“board; plank; ledge”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)latn-, *(s)lat- (“beam; log”). Cognate with Old High German latta (“lath”), (German Latte), Old English lætt (“lath”), Middle Low German lāde (“plank, counter, sales counter”), German Laden (“shop”). More at lath.

entries.meaning: A flat panel constructed with widely-spaced crossed thin strips of wood or other material, commonly used as a garden trellis.
(heraldry) A bearing with vertical and horizontal bands that cross each other.
(crystallography) A regular spacing or arrangement of geometric points, often decorated with a motif.
(group theory) A discrete subgroup of Rn which is isomorphic to Zn (considered as an additive group) and spans the real vector space Rn.
(music) A model of the tuning relationships of a just intonation system, comprising an array of points in a periodic multidimensional pattern.
(topology, Lie theory) A discrete subgroup L of a given locally compact group G whose quotient space G/L has finite invariant measure.
(algebra, order theory) A partially ordered set in which every pair of elements has a unique supremum and a unique infimum.

verbs.description: lattice (third-person singular simple present lattices, present participle latticing, simple past and past participle latticed)

entries.meaning: To close, as an opening, with latticework; to furnish with a lattice.
